entry.title: Galaxy Pipeline
entry.content:
This guide provides a flexible workflow for analyzing next-generation sequencing (NGS) data using Galaxy. Customize placeholders (e.g., [SPECIMEN_TYPE], [DISEASE_TYPE]) for your project.

Tutorial Sections

  • General Prerequisites
  • 1. Set Up Your Galaxy Environment
  • 2. Understand Your Sequencing Data
  • 3. Align Reads to a Reference Genome
  • 4. Call Variants
  • 5. Annotate Variants
  • 6. Visualize Variants
  • 7. Analyze and Interpret Results
  • 8. Assessment (Optional)
  • Tips for Customization
  • Suggested Illustrations

Set Up Your Galaxy Environment

Goal: Establish a workspace for data analysis. Steps:
  1. Visit Galaxy and register an account.
  2. Upload or access shared datasets.
  3. Navigate to "Histories Shared with Me" and import history.

Back to Tutorial Sections

Understand Your Sequencing Data

Goal: Assess the quality and structure of raw sequencing data. Steps:
  1. View FASTQ data and check sequencing quality.
  2. Run "FASTQ Quality Control" in Galaxy.
  3. Interpret quality scores based on ASCII Phred table.

Back to Tutorial Sections

Align Reads to a Reference Genome

Goal: Map sequencing reads to a reference genome. Steps:
  1. Use BWA-MEM to align reads.
  2. Sort BAM files using Picard.
  3. Mark duplicates and filter them.

Back to Tutorial Sections

Call Variants

Goal: Identify genetic variants from aligned reads. Steps:
  1. Run Samtools mpileup.
  2. Use VarScan and FreeBayes for variant calling.
  3. Compare results post-processing.

Back to Tutorial Sections

Annotate Variants

Goal: Add functional and clinical context to variants. Steps:
  1. Use wANNOVAR and VEP for annotation.
  2. Filter significant variants using external databases.

Back to Tutorial Sections

Visualize Variants

Goal: Inspect alignments and variants visually. Steps:
  1. Slice BAM file using Galaxy.
  2. Load BAM files into IGV.
  3. Zoom into regions of interest.

Back to Tutorial Sections

Analyze and Interpret Results

Goal: Generate insights from the analysis. Steps:
  1. Apply pipeline to your dataset.
  2. Identify key variants.
  3. Compare with external data sources.

Back to Tutorial Sections
